Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Gov. Tony Evers "canceled" the sales tax holiday, when in fact, it was not proposed or implemented by Republicans in 2019.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide evidence or specific examples to back up the assertion that Gov. Evers canceled the sales tax holiday.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the absence of a sales tax holiday in 2019 is solely due to Gov. Evers, without considering the role of Republican lawmakers who did not propose or pass legislation for it.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that Republicans prevented the 2018 back-to-school holiday from being offered in 2019 and subsequent years, as stated by Gov. Evers' spokesperson.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the sales tax holiday was not canceled by Gov. Evers, but rather not proposed or implemented by Republicans in 2019.
Understate: The claim understates the role of Republican lawmakers in the absence of the sales tax holiday by solely blaming Gov. Evers.
